Sue landlord and his law firm, do they need to hire other law firm to defend them to avoid conflicts of interest? - California Contracts Questions & Answers - Justia Ask a Lawyer
                If I sue the landlord’s law firm along with suing the landlord (because landlord's law firm had made false accusation to defame us, harassed and bullied us) in Civil Court, since landlord’s law firm is then also a defendant, would that be a “conflict of interest” for landlord’s law firm to use its own attorney to defend themselves and defend the landlord?  Do they all need to hire other law firms to defend themselves (defend the landlord and defend the landlord’s law firm) to avoid conflict of interest?
answer:
A:
						No. A conflict of interest would arise if the law firm previously represented you in the same or a substantially similar matter. The landlord's interests and the law firm's interests are aligned in defending the claims brought by you.  So there is no conflict of interest. Assuming you can overcome the privilege in connection with statements made during or in furtherance of litigation, the specific lawyer making the specific statement may be precluded from representing the law firm at trial if that lawyer will be a fact witness on a disputed question of fact, but another lawyer from the same firm would still be able to represent the law firm.

						The first thing you may want to try is going to the courthouse in the County where your father and his wife lived, and search the case files on the court’s database to see if there is an adoption case in your step-siblings’ names. question:
In Ch7 Bankruptcy can a Creditor demand access to / claim my old unsold screenplays as an IP/asset to satisfy the debt? - California Bankruptcy Questions & Answers - Justia Ask a Lawyer
                I’m a writer w/past success selling screenplays. Nothing got made and I’ve written nothing new in 10+ yrs.

A:
						When you file a chapter 7 bankruptcy, you are required to list all of your assets (including the screenplays that probably have no value) and list a market value, as well as all creditor claims (including pending litigation). Once you file, the litigation will be stayed and a chapter 7 trustee will be appointed. He or she will become the owner of all of your non-exempt assets (if your IP assets have no market value, they should still be listed as exempt assets). It's up to the trustee to determine whether these assets have any value to the bankruptcy estate and its creditors. If you can show that you've tried to sell your screenplays and have been unable to, the trustee will likely allow you to keep them free of any creditors claims. HOWEVER, if this person is bent on pursuing you, he or she will likely show up at hour 341(a) meeting with the trustt and try to convince the trustee to pursue the perceived value of your screenplays. In order to pursue the litigation against you, notwithstanding the bankruptcy, they will need to ask the Bankruptcy Court to lift the automatic stay. If that happens, I highly recommend that you consult an attorney with Bankruptcy Court experience. Most attorneys offer a free initial consultation. Good luck.
